html:
• Martin Jansson's Blog Posts: In-depth analysis and reverse engineering of the Makita battery communication protocol.
    • Specific adoption: Referenced its fundamental structure analysis of the communication protocol, especially the implementation logic of the checksum (CRC) algorithm, and the definition of physical layer connection pins.
    • Makita Battery Post 1
    • Makita Battery Post 2
  • GitHub - Belik1982/esp32-makita-bms-reader: An early and influential ESP32 implementation for reading Makita BMS data, a key reference for this project.
    • Specific adoption: Referenced its ESP32-side communication implementation flow, including the timing control for sending command sequences (like reading battery model, voltage data), and the parsing logic for some error codes.
    • Project Repository
  • Codeberg - Makita LXT Protocol: Provided invaluable protocol information and data structure definitions.
    • Specific adoption: Adopted its detailed memory map for accurately parsing various values in the response packets (such as manufacturing date format, cycle counts, over-discharge/over-load counters).
    • Project Repository
  • Done.land - Makita LXT Digital Interface: Detailed documentation on the digital interface and communication logic.
    • Specific adoption: Referenced its explanation of the battery interface's electrical characteristics to ensure correct hardware connection, and the understanding of communication handshake signals.
    • Article Link
  • GitHub - Open Battery Information: A collaborative project to document various battery protocols, including Makita's.
    • Specific adoption: Used as a cross-validation source for protocol command codes, confirming the definition of special commands like 0xB6 (clear fuse flag).
    • Project Repository
